titleStmt.title: A Description of Dr Delaney's Villa.

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: By Mr Sheridan.
Would you that Delville I describe,
Believe me, Sir, I will not gibe,
For who would be satyrical
Upon a thing so very small.You scarce upon the borders enter
Before you're at the very center.
A single crow can make it night,
When o're yr farm he takes his flight.
Yet in this narrow compass wee
Observe a vast variety.
Both Walks, Walls, Meadows & Parterres,
Windows, & doors, and Rooms, and stairs,
And Hills, and Dales, and Woods, and Fields,
And Hay, and Grass, & corn it yields.
All to your HaggardFarm yard brought so cheap in,
Without the mowing, or the reaping.
A Razor, thô to say't I'm loth,
Would shave you and yr meadows both.Thô small's the Farm, yet here's a house
Full large to entertain a mouse;
But where a rat is dreaded more
Than Savage Caledonian Boar;
For if 'tis enter'd by a rat,
There is no room to bring a Cat.A little rivulet seems to steal
Down through a thing you call a vale,
Like tears along a wrinkled cheek,
Like rain along a blade of leek;
And this you call your sweet Meander,
Which might be suck'd up by a Gander.
Could he but force his nether bill
To scoop the chanel of the rill.
I'm sure you'd make a mighty clutter,
Were it as big as city gutter.Next come I to your kitchin garden,
Which one poor mouse woud fare but hard in.
And round this garden is a walk,
No longer than a Taylor's chalk,
Thus I compute what space is in it,
A snail creeps round it in a minute.
One Lettice makes a shift to squeeze
Up through a tuft you call yr trees.
And once a year a single Rose
Peeps from the bud, but never blows.
In vain then you expect its bloom,
It cannot blow for want of ro
In short, in all your boasted seat,
There's nothing but your self that's Great.Y07B416B
